# Visual Hierarchy Rules

Always ensure clear distinction between:

1. Primary focus  
2. Supporting content  
3. Secondary details  

Use spacing before adding borders or dividers.

Whitespace is a design tool â€” use it generously.

---

# Typography Guidance

- Favor highly readable fonts.
- Maintain consistent scale.
- Avoid excessive font weights.
- Limit variation.

Typography alone should elevate the site.

---

# Color Discipline

Use color intentionally â€” not decoratively.

Guidelines:

- One primary color is often enough.
- Ensure strong contrast.
- Meet accessibility standards.
- Avoid overly saturated palettes.

When unsure:

ğŸ‘‰ Reduce color usage.

---

# Responsiveness (Mandatory)

Design mobile-first.

The site must look **excellent**, not merely functional, on:

- phones  
- tablets  
- laptops  
- large monitors  

Never allow:

- horizontal scrolling  
- cramped text  
- broken grids  
- tiny tap targets  

Mobile experience is not secondary.

---

# Performance Expectations

Static sites should feel instant.

Avoid introducing anything that harms perceived speed.

Prefer:

- lightweight assets  
- optimized images  
- minimal script usage  
- system capabilities over heavy libraries  

Speed directly influences perceived quality.

---

# Accessibility Baseline

Accessibility is part of good design.

Always ensure:

- sufficient color contrast  
- semantic structure  
- keyboard navigability  
- descriptive alt text  
- logical heading order  

Accessible design feels more professional to everyone.

---

# Interaction Design

Subtlety wins.

Prefer:

- short transitions  
- smooth hover states  
- gentle feedback  
- predictable behavior  

Avoid:

- long animations  
- dramatic motion  
- attention-seeking effects  

Motion should support usability â€” never compete with it.

---

# Layout Discipline

Use consistent spacing rules.

Maintain alignment.

Avoid uneven visual weight.

If a layout feels â€œalmost right,â€ refine it until it is unmistakably right.

Precision signals craftsmanship.

---

# Content Strategy

This website should communicate value quickly.

Within a few seconds, visitors should understand:

- who you are  
- what you do  
- what makes you credible  

Front-load important information.

Do not bury signal beneath decoration.

---

# What This Website Is NOT

- Not a playground  
- Not trend-chasing  
- Not animation-driven  
- Not experimental at the cost of usability  
- Not cluttered  

Restraint is a competitive advantage.
